head.title: Muscles and the Skeletal Muscular System

body.p: Think about the things you do during the day. Talking, walking, sitting, standing, shopping, cooking; all of these activities require movement of skeletal muscles. You even use skeletal muscles when you sleep: your diaphragm has to contract and relax for you to breathe. Think back to your study of the skeletal system and joints and remember that body movement occurs around the joints in the body when skeletal muscles pull on the bones making up the joints.

Of the four basic types of tissues, muscle is among the most abundant in animals. Muscle contractions are among the largest energy-consuming processes in the body, which is not surprising considering the work that muscles constantly do. The structure of muscles at the microscopic level allows them to convert the chemical energy found in ATP into the mechanical energy of movement.

The body contains three types of muscle tissue: skeletal muscle
muscle that moves bones and produces movement , cardiac muscle
muscle found in the heart , and smooth muscle
involuntary muscle of blood vessels and other internal organs, such as stomach and bladder
. As already mentioned, skeletal muscle is responsible for lifting, walking, and many other forms of movement. Cardiac muscle in your heart beats day and night every day of your life. Smooth muscles help regulate constriction or dilation of the blood vessels in the cardiovascular system, the bronchioles in the respiratory system and the intestines in the digestive system. All of these muscles have some properties in common, including the ability to contract, to be electrically excited, and to regain their forms after being stretched or contracted. At the molecular level, all muscles generate force as a result of interactions between myosin
protein that makes up thick filaments and actin
protein that makes up thin filaments filaments. However, the different muscle types have slightly different microscopic structures, and the differences in structure relate to their different functions. Their locations in the body reflect their different roles in body function. Click here to see the introductory overview of the muscular system from unit 1.
